source.name: SF Environment / Recology San Francisco
source.notes: Based on official SF Environment and Recology San Francisco guidelines. SF has mandatory recycling and composting with a 3-bin system (blue/green/black). Fines apply for non-compliance.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
notes: SF accepts all rigid plastics in the blue bin
No need to remove labels
commonMistakes: Don't crush bottles — leave them intact with caps on
Don't include bottles with significant food residue

materials.name: Plastic tubs, clamshells and containers
notes: SF recycles all rigid plastics regardless of resin number
Includes clamshells, tubs, cups, lids, and trays
commonMistakes: Don't put in plastic bags — place items directly in the blue bin
Don't include Styrofoam containers (those go in the black bin)

materials.name: Plastic cups and lids
instructions: Place cups and lids in BLUE bin
notes: Rigid plastic cups and lids are accepted in SF's blue bin
Includes clear and colored plastic cups
commonMistakes: Don't include Styrofoam cups (black bin)
Don't include cups with heavy food residue — rinse first

materials.name: Plastic buckets
instructions: Remove any metal handles if possible
notes: Rigid plastic buckets are recyclable in SF
Must be empty and clean — no paint or chemical residue
commonMistakes: Don't include buckets with dried paint or chemicals (hazardous waste)

materials.name: Plastic toys (no batteries or metal)
instructions: Remove all batteries and metal parts first
Place plastic-only toys in BLUE bin
notes: Only all-plastic toys are accepted
Toys with batteries or electronics go to e-waste drop-off
commonMistakes: Don't include toys with batteries or electronic components
Don't include stuffed animals or fabric toys (donate or trash)

materials.name: Plastic bags and film wrap
instructions: Collect all plastic bags and film in one bag
Place the tied bag in the BLUE bin
notes: SF is unusual: plastic bags CAN go in the blue bin, but ONLY if contained inside a tied plastic bag
Loose plastic film will jam machinery — always bag it first
This includes grocery bags, produce bags, bread bags, dry cleaning bags, and bubble wrap
commonMistakes: NEVER put loose plastic bags or film in the blue bin
Don't use plastic bags to collect other recyclables — only bag plastic bags/film together
examples: Dry cleaning bags (in a tied bag)

materials.name: Newspapers
instructions: No need to remove inserts or staples
notes: Includes all newspaper inserts, circulars, and supplements
commonMistakes: Don't put wet or soiled newspaper in the blue bin — compost it in the green bin instead

materials.name: Magazines and catalogs
instructions: No need to remove staples or subscription cards
notes: Glossy and coated paper is accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include paper contaminated with food or grease (compost those)

materials.name: Office paper and mail
notes: Includes all clean, dry paper: printer paper, mail, envelopes, sticky notes
Shredded paper should be placed in a paper bag before going in the blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or napkins (those go in the green bin)
Don't include thermal receipts (trash)

materials.name: Phone books
notes: No need to remove covers or binding

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Can also be used to contain shredded paper
notes: Clean paper bags go in the blue bin
Greasy or food-soiled paper bags should go in the green bin
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper bags in blue bin — compost them in the green bin

materials.name: Cardboard boxes
instructions: Remove packing materials (bubble wrap, styrofoam peanuts)
notes: All clean corrugated cardboard is accepted
Waxed cardboard goes in the green bin
commonMistakes: Don't include waxed cardboard (green bin for composting)
Don't include cardboard heavily soaked with grease (green bin)

materials.name: Paperboard (cereal boxes, shoe boxes)
instructions: Flatten and place in BLUE bin
notes: Includes thin cardboard like cereal boxes, shoe boxes, and product packaging
commonMistakes: Don't include paperboard contaminated with food (compost it)

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Lids can stay on or be recycled separately
notes: All colors of glass (clear, green, brown) are accepted
No need to remove labels
commonMistakes: Don't include window glass, mirrors, or plate glass
Don't include ceramics, pottery, or Pyrex
Don't include drinking glasses or crystal

materials.name: Aluminum cans
notes: Crushing is fine but not required
commonMistakes: Don't include aerosol cans that aren't completely empty

materials.name: Tin and steel cans
notes: Includes all food cans, pet food cans, and other steel/tin containers
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue — give them a quick rinse

materials.name: Aluminum foil and pie tins
instructions: Ball up small pieces of foil into a larger ball (at least 2 inches)
notes: Clean aluminum foil, trays, and pie tins are all accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include heavily soiled foil that can't be cleaned

materials.name: Empty aerosol cans
notes: Only completely empty aerosol cans go in the blue bin
Partially full aerosol cans are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't put partially full aerosol cans in the blue bin — take them to Household Hazardous Waste
Don't puncture aerosol cans

materials.name: Milk, juice and broth cartons
notes: Includes gable-top cartons (milk) and aseptic cartons (juice boxes, broth)
Ice cream cartons are also accepted
commonMistakes: Don't flatten aseptic cartons — leave them as-is

materials.name: Paper coffee cups (with sleeves and lids)
instructions: Keep the sleeve and lid on — they're all accepted together
notes: SF is one of the few cities that accepts paper coffee cups in recycling!
The plastic lid, paper sleeve, and paper cup all go together in the blue bin
This applies to standard paper hot cups with a plastic or wax lining
commonMistakes: Don't assume paper cups are trash — SF recycles them
Don't put Styrofoam cups in the blue bin (those go in the black bin)
examples: Paper coffee cup with lid and sleeve

materials.name: Metal lids and bottle caps
instructions: Small lids and caps can fall through sorting equipment
Place small caps inside a steel can and crimp the top to contain them, or leave on bottles
notes: Metal lids from jars and small bottle caps are all recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put loose small caps directly in the bin — they fall through sorting screens

materials.name: Books
notes: Consider donating books in good condition to the SF Public Library or local Little Free Libraries
commonMistakes: Don't include 3-ring binders (remove the metal rings first)

materials.name: Food scraps (all types)
instructions: Place ALL food scraps in the GREEN bin
No need to separate types — everything goes together
notes: SF composting is MANDATORY under city ordinance — fines apply for non-compliance
SF accepts ALL food scraps including meat, bones, dairy, and seafood
Recology's motto: 'Anything that was once alive' goes in the green bin
SF composts approximately 750 tons daily
commonMistakes: Don't put food scraps in the black bin — it's against SF law
Don't use regular plastic bags to collect food scraps (use BPI-certified compostable bags or paper bags)

materials.name: Fruit and vegetable scraps
notes: All fruit and vegetable scraps, peels, cores, and rinds are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put produce stickers in the green bin if possible (remove them)

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: All meat including bones, fat, and gristle are accepted
notes: SF's industrial composting facility can process all meat and bones
This includes raw and cooked meat of all types
commonMistakes: Don't throw meat in the trash — SF mandates composting
Don't worry about cooked vs raw — both go in the green bin

materials.name: Seafood and shells
instructions: Place all seafood scraps and shells in GREEN bin
notes: SF composting accepts all seafood including shells, bones, and skin
commonMistakes: Don't put seafood packaging (plastic trays, shrink wrap) in the green bin

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Place dairy products in GREEN bin
notes: All dairy products are accepted in SF's green bin
Includes spoiled milk, cheese rinds, yogurt, butter, and cream
commonMistakes: Don't include the plastic container — only the dairy product itself
Rinse and recycle dairy containers in the blue bin

materials.name: Bread, grains and pasta
notes: All grain products, baked goods, and pasta are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include the plastic bag — just the food

materials.name: Eggshells
notes: Eggshells are great for composting

materials.name: Coffee grounds and paper filters
instructions: Place coffee grounds and paper filters together in GREEN bin
Remove grounds from K-cups/pods first (pod goes in trash)
notes: Paper coffee filters compost along with the grounds
commonMistakes: Don't include K-cup/Nespresso pods (trash or check manufacturer take-back)
Don't include metal mesh filters (those are reusable)

materials.name: Tea bags
instructions: Remove any staples or tags if easy to do so
notes: Most tea bags are compostable
Some premium tea bags have nylon mesh — those go in trash
commonMistakes: Don't include tea bags with nylon/silk mesh (trash them)

materials.name: Soiled paper napkins and paper towels
notes: All food-soiled paper goes in the green bin
Includes napkins, paper towels, tissues, and facial tissue
commonMistakes: Don't put these in the blue bin — they cannot be recycled
Don't put these in the trash — they're compostable

materials.name: Pizza boxes (greasy)
instructions: Greasy or food-soiled pizza boxes go in the green bin
notes: In SF, greasy pizza boxes go in the green compost bin, not recycling
Clean pizza boxes with no grease stains can go in the blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't try to recycle a greasy pizza box — it contaminates recycling
If it's completely clean (no grease), you can put it in the blue bin

materials.name: Paper takeout containers (food-soiled)
instructions: Place food-soiled paper containers in GREEN bin
notes: Food-soiled paper and cardboard food containers go in the green bin
Clean paper containers can go in the blue bin
commonMistakes: Don't include containers with plastic or wax coating (trash)

materials.name: Paper plates and bowls (soiled)
instructions: Place food-soiled paper plates and bowls in GREEN bin
notes: Soiled paper plates and bowls are compostable
Plastic-coated plates go in the trash
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic-coated or Styrofoam plates (trash)
Don't include ceramic plates (trash if broken, donate if intact)

materials.name: Wood items (chopsticks, toothpicks, stirrers, popsicle sticks)
notes: Untreated, unpainted wood items are compostable
Includes chopsticks, popsicle sticks, toothpicks, coffee stirrers, and wooden utensils
commonMistakes: Don't include painted, stained, or pressure-treated wood
Don't include wood with metal attachments

materials.name: Yard waste, plants and flowers
instructions: Cut large branches to fit in the bin
notes: All yard and garden waste goes in the green bin
Includes leaves, grass, flowers, plants, and small branches
commonMistakes: Don't put yard waste in plastic bags — place it directly in the green bin or use compostable bags
Don't include large tree limbs (call Recology at (415) 330-1300 for pickup)

materials.name: BPI-certified compostable bags
instructions: Use BPI-certified compostable bags to line your green bin or collect food scraps
Place bag and contents in GREEN bin
notes: ONLY BPI-certified compostable bags are accepted — look for the BPI logo
Regular plastic bags labeled 'biodegradable' are NOT accepted
commonMistakes: Don't use regular plastic bags in the green bin — they contaminate compost
Don't confuse 'biodegradable' with 'compostable' — look for BPI certification

materials.name: Nut shells
notes: All nut shells are compostable

materials.name: Hair and pet fur
notes: Human hair, pet fur, and feathers are all compostable
commonMistakes: Don't include hair with chemical treatments attached to non-compostable materials

materials.name: Waxed cardboard
instructions: Break down and place in GREEN bin
notes: Waxed cardboard cannot be recycled but can be composted in SF
commonMistakes: Don't put waxed cardboard in the blue bin — the wax coating prevents recycling

materials.name: Tissue paper and gift wrapping (non-metallic)
instructions: Remove any tape, ribbons, or bows first
notes: Plain tissue paper and non-metallic wrapping paper are compostable
Metallic or glitter wrapping paper goes in the trash
commonMistakes: Don't include metallic, glittery, or plastic-coated wrapping paper (trash)

materials.name: Chip bags and candy wrappers
notes: These are multi-layer materials (plastic + foil) that cannot be recycled or composted
Even though they may look metallic, they are not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put these in the blue bin — they are not recyclable aluminum
Don't put in the green bin — they are not compostable

materials.name: Styrofoam (expanded polystyrene)
notes: Styrofoam is not recyclable or compostable in SF
SF banned Styrofoam food service containers — but you may still encounter foam packaging
commonMistakes: Don't put Styrofoam in the blue bin — it contaminates recycling
Don't confuse rigid plastic containers (recyclable) with foam (not recyclable)

materials.name: Diapers and sanitary products
notes: Diapers and sanitary products cannot be recycled or composted
commonMistakes: Don't put in the green bin even though they contain organic material

materials.name: Cat litter and pet waste
instructions: Bag it and place in BLACK bin
notes: Pet waste and cat litter are NOT accepted in SF's green bin
Dog waste from public areas should be bagged and placed in any public trash can
commonMistakes: Don't put pet waste in the green bin — it can contain pathogens
Don't flush cat litter — it can harm marine life

materials.name: Broken ceramics, pottery and porcelain
instructions: Wrap broken pieces in newspaper or paper
notes: Ceramics, pottery, and porcelain cannot be recycled — they contaminate glass recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put ceramics in the blue bin — they look like glass but aren't recyclable
Don't put Pyrex or tempered glass in the blue bin either

materials.name: Mirrors and window glass
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
notes: Window glass and mirrors have different melting points than container glass and cannot be recycled together
commonMistakes: Don't put mirrors or window glass in the blue bin

materials.name: Drinking glasses, Pyrex and crystal
notes: Drinkware and Pyrex have different compositions than container glass
Donate intact glassware instead of trashing it
commonMistakes: Don't put drinking glasses in the blue bin with bottles and jars

materials.name: Thermal receipts
notes: Thermal receipts contain BPA and cannot be recycled or composted
commonMistakes: Don't put receipts in the blue or green bin — the thermal coating contaminates other materials

materials.name: Rubber bands
notes: Rubber bands are not recyclable or compostable

materials.name: Pens, pencils and markers
notes: Mixed-material items like pens and markers are not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put these in the blue bin

materials.name: Cigarette butts
notes: Cigarette filters are made of plastic (cellulose acetate) and are not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't litter cigarette butts — they are the most common form of ocean pollution

materials.name: Disposable face masks
instructions: Cut the ear loops to protect wildlife
notes: Disposable masks are made of polypropylene plastic and cannot be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put masks in the blue or green bin

materials.name: Sponges
notes: Most kitchen sponges are synthetic and not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put sponges in the green bin — most contain plastic

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate usable clothing to thrift stores or clothing donation bins
Damaged textiles and rags can go in the BLACK bin
Do NOT place clothing in the blue or green bin
notes: SF has numerous textile donation bins and thrift stores
Recology recommends donating usable clothing rather than trashing it
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in the blue recycling bin
Don't throw away usable clothing — donate it

materials.name: Batteries (all types)
instructions: NEVER put batteries in any curbside bin
Tape the terminals of lithium and 9V batteries to prevent fires
Drop off at SF Household Hazardous Waste facility or participating retail locations
notes: Batteries are hazardous waste in SF
Many hardware stores and electronics retailers accept batteries for recycling
Lithium batteries are a fire risk in trash and recycling trucks
commonMistakes: NEVER put batteries in the blue bin — they cause fires in recycling trucks
Don't put batteries in the trash either

materials.name: Paint (latex and oil-based)
instructions: Take to SF Household Hazardous Waste facility
Do NOT pour paint down drains
Dried latex paint (less than 1 inch in the can) can go in the BLACK bin with the lid off
notes: Liquid paint is hazardous waste
SF Household Hazardous Waste: 501 Tunnel Ave, San Francisco — open Thursday–Saturday
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain or into storm drains
Don't put liquid paint cans in any curbside bin

materials.name: Motor oil and automotive fluids
instructions: Take to SF Household Hazardous Waste facility
Keep in original containers if possible
Many auto parts stores also accept used motor oil
notes: Never pour motor oil or auto fluids down drains or into the ground
commonMistakes: Don't pour oil down the drain — one quart of oil can contaminate 250,000 gallons of water

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes and CFL bulbs
instructions: Take to SF Household Hazardous Waste facility
Some hardware stores accept CFL bulbs
notes: Fluorescent tubes and CFLs contain mercury and are hazardous waste
Incandescent and LED bulbs can go in the BLACK bin (not hazardous)
commonMistakes: Don't put fluorescent bulbs in any curbside bin
Don't break them — mercury vapor is harmful

materials.name: Incandescent and LED light bulbs
instructions: Wrap in paper or place in original packaging
notes: Incandescent, LED, and halogen bulbs are not hazardous but also not recyclable
Fluorescent and CFL bulbs are different — those are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't confuse these with fluorescent/CFL bulbs (which are hazardous waste)

materials.name: Pesticides, herbicides and household chemicals
instructions: Take to SF Household Hazardous Waste facility
notes: All pesticides, solvents, and corrosive household chemicals are hazardous waste
SF Household Hazardous Waste: 501 Tunnel Ave, open Thursday–Saturday
commonMistakes: Don't pour chemicals down drains or into garbage
Don't mix different chemicals together — dangerous reactions can occur

materials.name: Medications and pharmaceuticals
instructions: Use a drug take-back location (SF pharmacies, SFPD stations)
Do NOT flush medications or put them in the trash
Check sfenvironment.org for nearby take-back locations
notes: Many Walgreens and CVS locations in SF have drug take-back kiosks
SFPD stations also accept medications
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications — they contaminate water
Don't put medications in any curbside bin

materials.name: Propane tanks and compressed gas cylinders
instructions: Take to SF Household Hazardous Waste facility
Do NOT put in any curbside bin
Some propane exchange locations accept old tanks
notes: Pressurized containers are extremely dangerous in recycling and garbage trucks
commonMistakes: NEVER put propane tanks or compressed gas in any bin — they can explode

materials.name: Electronics and e-waste
instructions: Take to a certified e-waste recycler or SF Household Hazardous Waste facility
Erase personal data from devices before disposal
Do NOT put electronics in any curbside bin
notes: SF Household Hazardous Waste facility accepts electronics
Best Buy and Goodwill also accept many electronics for recycling
California law prohibits putting e-waste in the trash
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in any curbside bin
Don't forget to erase personal data first

materials.name: Mattresses and box springs
instructions: Schedule a bulky item pickup with Recology at (415) 330-1300
Or take to a mattress recycling facility
notes: Recology offers free bulky item pickups for SF residents
California law requires mattress recycling — do not put in a dumpster
commonMistakes: Don't leave mattresses on the street — schedule a pickup
Don't put in regular bins

materials.name: Large appliances
instructions: Schedule a bulky item pickup with Recology at (415) 330-1300
Or arrange haul-away through your appliance retailer when purchasing a replacement
notes: Recology provides free bulky item pickup for SF residents
Appliances contain metals that are valuable for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't leave appliances on the sidewalk without scheduling a pickup

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Small amounts of cooking oil can go in the GREEN bin
Pour small amounts onto paper towels or newspaper and compost together
Large quantities (more than a cup) should go to a cooking oil drop-off
notes: Do NOT pour oil down the drain — it causes sewer blockages
commonMistakes: Don't pour cooking oil down the drain
Don't put large amounts of liquid oil directly in the green bin

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place shredded paper inside a paper bag
Staple or fold the bag closed
notes: Loose shredded paper jams sorting equipment
Always contain it in a paper bag before recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper directly in the blue bin

materials.name: Scrap metal
instructions: Place small scrap metal in BLUE bin
Large metal items should be scheduled for bulky pickup with Recology at (415) 330-1300
notes: Clean scrap metal is recyclable
Place small items like nails and screws in a sealed can to prevent injury
commonMistakes: Don't include metal with hazardous coatings or chemicals
examples: Loose nails in a sealed can

recycle: All rigid plastics (bottles, tubs, cups, lids, clamshells, buckets)
Paper coffee cups with sleeves and lids
Plastic bags and wrap (MUST be in a tied plastic bag)
Paper: newspapers, magazines, office paper, mail, phone books
Metal: aluminum cans, tin/steel cans, foil, pie tins
Milk, juice, broth and ice cream cartons
Books and shredded paper (in paper bag)
compost: ALL food scraps — including meat, bones, seafood, dairy, shells
Coffee grounds with paper filters, tea bags
Soiled paper: napkins, paper towels, tissues
Wood items: chopsticks, toothpicks, stirrers, popsicle sticks
Tissue paper and non-metallic wrapping paper
Small amounts of cooking oil (on paper)
trash: Chip bags, candy wrappers, mylar packaging
Mirrors, window glass, Pyrex, drinking glasses

recycle: Loose plastic bags or film (must be contained in a tied bag)
Window glass, mirrors, or drinking glasses

tips: SF has MANDATORY recycling and composting — fines apply for putting recyclables or compostables in the trash
Blue bin = Recycling, Green bin = Composting, Black bin = Landfill
SF accepts paper coffee cups in the blue bin — sleeves and lids included!
Plastic bags CAN go in the blue bin but ONLY inside a tied plastic bag
Green bin rule of thumb: 'anything that was once alive' plus food-soiled paper
SF composting is comprehensive: meat, bones, seafood, dairy, shells all go in the green bin
Rinse containers — they don't need to be spotless, just reasonably clean
Flatten cardboard boxes to save space
When in doubt, visit SFRecycles.org or call Recology at (415) 330-1300
Batteries and electronics are NEVER accepted in curbside bins — use drop-off
Schedule free bulky item pickups through Recology

locations.name: Recology San Francisco (Customer Service)
accepts: Bulky item pickup (free for SF residents)
locations.notes: Call to schedule free bulky item pickup

locations.name: SFRecycles.org — Sorting Guide
accepts: Online sorting guide for any item
locations.notes: Use the online search tool to look up how to dispose of any item in SF
